Amidst the chaos of our healthcare system, the plight of the mentally challenged and Alzheimer's patients with additional medical needs remains overlooked. A friend of mine was recently discharged from St. Mary's in Grand Junction, having sustained a hip fracture and living with Alzheimer's. Shockingly, they provided no rehabilitation for her hip injury and no open beds for Alzheimer's patients.

The absurdity does not end there. Last year, authorities shut down a facility that catered to those with developmental challenges to make way for "challenged" residents in Denver. This decision was as ludicrous as it was insensitive.

Our healthcare system seems to have forgotten the essence of compassion, focusing instead on the bottom line. It is a heart-wrenching reality that drug addicts and emergency room managers can receive care, while our elderly population, dealing with health issues, are treated as second-class citizens.

The sadness in this situation is palpable. It is a shame that in the midst of technological advancements and medical breakthroughs, we are neglecting the most vulnerable among us. We must not allow our elected representatives to turn a blind eye to this crisis. It is time to demand dignity and compassion in end-of-life care for all.

Politicians, hear us loud and clear: We will not stand idly by while those who need it most are left to fend for themselves. It is time to support a bill that prioritizes the needs of the mentally challenged and Alzheimer's patients, ensuring they receive the care they deserve. Let us stand up for what is right and fight for their dignity.
